title: Brooklyn man pleads guilty in accidental fatal shooting of friend
content:
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- A Brooklyn man pleaded guilty Monday to accidentally shooting and killing his friend when he placed a gun he thought was unloaded to her back and pulled the trigger.
Michael Lancaster, 22, pleaded guilty to reckless homicide with an automatic three-year sentencing enhancement for using a gun in the Feb. 3 death of 18-year-old Olivia Stull.
Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Judge Dick Ambrose will sentence Lancaster on Dec. 6. Lancaster will have to serve at least three years in prison and the rest of the sentence will be left up to Ambrose, defense attorney Stephen McGowan said.
Lancaster and Stull were inside Lancaster's Ridge Road apartment in Brooklyn getting ready to paint when Lancaster put a gun to Stull's back with the intent to have it make a clicking sound.
Lancaster told police he took the magazine out of the handgun and thought that would prevent the gun from firing, according to court records.
The gun had one bullet in the chamber and Lancaster shot Stull in the back. Stull was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center, where she was pronounced dead.
Lancaster called Brooklyn police immediately after the shooting and said he shot his roommate, police said. Lancaster and Stull had not been drinking or taking drugs, McGowan said.
McGowan said Lancaster was "seriously emotionally affected" by the shooting and never meant for anything bad to happen.
"It was totally unintentional but it was a horrible situation," McGowan said.
